Short version: 43%If you like generic anime style pictures, you may like this entry in the Pixel Puzzle series. But, like in the other games, don’t expect any replay value over the pre-defined two dozen or so jigsaw pictures.Long version:One of the advantages—and at the same time, the main disadvantage—of the Pixel Puzzles series is that all games are essentially the same: you get a set amount of jigsaw puzzles with pre-set tile shapes and numbers, and that is it.The result is that each Pixel Puzzle game boils down to whether you like the theme of its pictures, which in our cases is anime style ones. (None of the pictures are from any actual anime, they are just decent-ish drawings.)The inherent problem with drawn pictures instead of photos in a jigsaw puzzle is that sometimes it is a lot more difficult to determine where a tile goes. In some of the pictures here, this goes to rather extremes; this never reaches frustrating levels, but the game feels like a step back from other entries.Also, as a final note: while the ambient music is not bad, I really advise to mute the game, because the overly enthusiastic fairy helper can get on one’s nerves rather fast.

												What is Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime?Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime is a strong contestant for the "doesn't know the difference between anime and manga" award. Other than that, it is a puzzle game. You are presented with 25 puzzles that range from 60 to 350 pieces each, with only one having 350 pieces. There is one assistant flying around giving you bubbles you can use for optional help.The graphics are fitting for a puzzle game, but the puzzle pictures sometimes, as you will know from the puzzles by a big German company "Ravensburger", if you ever laid them, make it difficult to see where you would want to fit tiles. This however is remedied by the gameplay (see below).The music is not disturbing and fitting for the theme, but the spoken words are annoying. In fact I shut the sound off completely after a while and heard podcasts while playing this, as I prefer to do with relaxing games. Your (fairy?) helper always tells things that are funny the first time but get annoying later. For example while she gives you energy bubbles (see below) she says "This is because I love you" and such nonsense. I'm not certain if this is aimed at cliché nerds with anime bedsheets or a parody of their hikikomori lifestyle, in either case it is an annoyance to me the third or fourth time, losing its fun to become a Navi-esque bother.The gameplay is where a puzzle game rises or falls. There are several aspects to be considered by a developer, and I think in this case they are well covered. At first there is progression: The levels can be progressed through on a grid. Progress within levels is - surprisingly, I must say after playing the previous game - saved even after exiting a puzzle. Great plus! I did not test if you can have multiple puzzles saved at the same time, but I assume so since I started others up in-between, although not laying any pieces there, and the developer says on the forum that every piece laid is saved.The second aspect is on the puzzle itself, the motifs. These are okay but repetitive. You usually see some kawaii guy or girl, rarely a couple, in front of some background. The third aspect is how you grab pieces. This is well executed in the entire series. Around the puzzle there is a basin filled with water (see the store page screenshots). You can take any piece at any time. If you want to save it for later, just lay it somewhere on the board. A propos "laying on the board" - if you lay a piece correctly rotated close to where it should be, it snaps in automatically and can't be accidentally removed. This is the same in the entire series, but worth mentioning. The fourth and final consideration is what to do if you get stuck. There are some optional hints which you can use. I never used any of them, so I can't say how they work, but from what I gathered you can see the board motif (which could be done outside the game in a gallery as well, but here you see it directly on the board) or show where a piece you hold belongs to. There are several other buttons but I didn't press any, as I said. Probably you can also change the background color of the cardboard you lay the puzzle on.The controls are easy: You only need a mouse, and once the space key to enter the main menu. This is actually annoying, as each time you want to play, all puzzles except one are accessed on the second screen only for which you need an additional click and spacebar press.So what is the length of the game? Assuming you take your time without resorting to any of the help features, you can realistically expect 15-25 hours of gameplay, depending on how good a puzzler you are. If you use the ingame help, this might be shorter, I can't say it since I did not test it.Would I recommend this game? Only to puzzle fans or such looking for a relaxing gameplay. If you need fast action, you're wrong here. If you want puzzles, you can grab this. While this is far from perfect, it is a game puzzle fans will enjoy - even if most likely with at least the speech turned off.

												Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime belongs to a series of games focusing on jigsaw mechanics on a thematic. The previous ones are about Zombies, Japan or Birds. Anime is adding rotation and a character to guide you and to help you. However, I can understand those that can be bored by it, as it's a question also of patience. Some puzzles requires really time to be finished and once it's done, the satisfaction is great.Yeah, I recommend this one. I suppose that the fairy will annoy many of the players but don't let the game being reduced to that. It's still a good moment to pass.

												It's a jigsaw puzzle simulator, featuring the world's most unbelievably infuriating mascot.  The rules are fairly simple, and made simpler by the fact that the pieces "snap into place" even when there's no other pieces nearby to snap into.  This means you can blindly try pieces in all the locations until it fits... but since some of the puzzles have hundreds of "slots" to try, you're going to be blindly slapping around for hours if you try it.  Unfortunately, the oftentimes repeated patterns or large swaths of flat color, combined with the same piece ends repeated over and over result in blind guess-and-check play, like it or not.Also, the "harder" puzzles (although there's no lose condition, outside of getting bored and quitting,) have pieces that are at times downright TINY, and you're going to be staring at them for a while.  If your vision isn't so great, prepare for headaches and eye strain, beause we're talking about searching for straight edge pieces when the pieces are only about 12 pixels across to start with!There's a few "pixel dust powers" you get whenever the insufferable "pixel pixie" feels like giving you "pixel dust" (which is at random time intervals and randomly after placing a puzzle piece) that let you automatically rotate the piece to the correct spot, get to view what the picture is supposed to look like, or just tell you where that one individual piece goes, but they cost progressively more pixel dust for each one, and so it's usually best to just use it to get the (cheapest) right rotation on the indistinguishable background pieces, so you only have to blindly push it through every possible slot once, instead of once per possible rotation.I only got this game in a bundle, and would never have bought it specifically because the art is only mediocre, and the pixie mascot character is such a terrible Deviant Art monstrosity even BEFORE I heard her speak.  Move over, Navi, there's a new champion of annoyingly excited lines said a billion times.  Prepare for a fairy that will shout "WOOHOO! YAY! YOU GOT THIS! THIS IS EASY! YAY! YOU GOT THIS! YOU GOT THIS!" for every piece you place in puzzles that have hundreds of pieces.There IS a button (appropriately enough, delete,) that makes the annoying pixie go away, but it also means you give up your pixel dust powers, so you're stuck blindly moving your background pieces around until it snaps into place.  Ultimately, if you're someone who would like to make a jigsaw puzzle of anime characters, you're probably better served getting a real one, and sparing your nerves the annoyances of this game.  Then again, real ones cost more, so maybe you can consider this a discount puzzle game where you have to put up with the infuriating mascot as a pennance? Still, I can't imagine there aren't free browser games like this that don't have that horrible fairy in it.

In this game you are presented by 25 different "anime"puzzles ranging from 60 to 350 pieces, and you're assisted by an annoying "fairy" that throw on you some kind of dust that helps you to correct the rotation of the piece, show the location of it or to flash ghost the image which can be very VERY helpful in the big puzzles with +200 pieces. 												This game is terrible.  Not because it's just a jigsaw puzzle game.  I wouldn't have bothered getting or playing this at all if that were the case.  The issue is that pretty much every aspect of its design is flawed.  It plays background music in the form of a single track that loops endlessly, which is a harmless enough little tune, but gets tiring with no variety for any of the 25 puzzles the game has.  Thankfully you can mute it in the options menu, which you'll do if for no other reason than to shut up that stupid fairy.  Whoever programmed that in was a jackass.  The fairy talks way too much and says annoying things, taunting and harassing you constantly.  Even though you can make it go away as you work on the puzzle (which removes the ability to use hints), because at least somebody had a shred of common sense, it still bothers you in the menu screen.  I can go to the puzzle select screen and before five seconds have passed, it'll start bugging me to hurry up and pick one.  I could understand if I was just sitting there for a minute or two without choosing a puzzle or exiting out, but when I have barely had a chance to look at any of them it needs to shut up and leave me alone.As you work on the puzzles the pieces float around the edge of the board, constantly moving, which is really annoying.  It isn't helpful and it doesn't make the game more interesting, so why make them move around?  If nothing else let me turn that feature off so I can find pieces more easily.  The puzzle pieces snap to the correct spot on the board, if they're rotated the right way, but even if you have two pieces lined up properly, knowing they fit together, they will not connect unless you find their proper place on the board first.  That's really annoying when you find pieces that line up but aren't able to work out where they go on the board, meaning you have to use a hint to find out where one of them goes.Rotating the puzzle pieces can be annoying because in order to do so you have to hold the left mouse button down, selecting the piece, and then right click it.  If you aren't holding it with the left mouse button and right click on it, it gets flung back in with the other pieces around the edge.  I don't need a button that does that, as I can always easily drag a piece off of the board.  Instead, allow me to easily rotate each piece by simply right clicking while my cursor hovers over it.The pictures used for the puzzles aren't really interesting.  It just has people standing around in various environments.  There's no action or dynamism to what they're doing.  It could have involved pictures of combat, magic, slapstick, or anything happening, but that isn't what we got.  Many of the color palettes were quite aggravating as well, as they would use similar shades in multiple parts of the same image.  This wouldn't have been such a problem if you were allowed to reference the image of the puzzle whenever you wanted, but to do that you have to use one of your hints.  Why does reviewing the image require the use of a hint?  It doesn't help you place any of the puzzle pieces.  It's no different than just looking at the picture on the box and nobody would call that cheating or using a hint. This game is a great demonstration for why real-life jigsaw puzzles are better, as the biggest puzzle in this game is 350 pieces.  In real life, that would be a pretty small puzzle, but it's a nightmare to play on the computer.  The pieces are so small that it's very arduous to work on it.  The best puzzles were the smaller ones, making it feel like more of a punishment than a reward as you unlocked the larger ones.  To think that a 60 piece puzzle was even programmed into this game, when that wouldn't even be bothered with by a child over the age of 7, is a real testament to how poorly this game was implemented.I don't recommend this game at all and am honestly shocked it's reviewed so highly.  It's a puzzle to me.

Holding them and right-clicking will rotate the pieces and they will click into place if let go near their correct location. There are three bonuses you can use (ghost image, correct rotation of piece, correct location of piece) to make it a little easier but is by no means required in order to solve these. There is also an option to show a small strip along the bottom to temporarily place pieces without them floating about so you can organize some by color and such before final placement.The main difference in Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime from the others in the franchise is that there's an anime pixie floating around when solving puzzles who is extremely hyper and will not stop talking. It can be considered cute and funny at first but that may end very quickly once you keep hearing the same lines on repeat (including one which is grammatically incorrect). It is not possible to disable the pixie and the lines can not be muted apart from muting the entire game.

TL;DReview: Typical jigsaw puzzle and not deviating much from any of the other Pixel Puzzle games in the franchise. It's not great but hey, it's a jigsaw puzzle. Can't expect too much from a jigsaw puzzle game.Defining feature: Floating Pixie that won't stop talking. May have to mute the game.Bugs: None encountered.Achievements: 100% completion possible in a single play-through.Final Verdict: 5/10The pieces float in water around the table frame for the puzzle. Holding them and right-clicking will rotate the pieces and they will click into place if let go near their correct location. There are three bonuses you can use (ghost image, correct rotation of piece, correct location of piece) to make it a little easier but is by no means required in order to solve these. There is also an option to show a small strip along the bottom to temporarily place pieces without them floating about so you can organize some by color and such before final placement.The main difference in Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime from the others in the franchise is that there's an anime pixie floating around when solving puzzles who is extremely hyper and will not stop talking. It can be considered cute and funny at first but that may end very quickly once you keep hearing the same lines on repeat (including one which is grammatically incorrect). It is not possible to disable the pixie and the lines can not be muted apart from muting the entire game.

												Really liked this puzzle game, it's fun and the images are great (I like Anime)..I don't understand why some people seem to nag about needing dust for rotating the pieces, you don't need dust for rotating the pieces, you can just use the mousebutton for that. Yeah you need dust if you want it to automatically rotate to the correct position..Also some people seem to hate the imp, but you can just turn her off with <delete> (or use the option)..And there is a save function, if you leave the puzzle, and come back later, it's still as you left it, any loose pieces you left on the board are floating again, that's all.And the floating pieces makes the game more interesting, at least to me, it adds another dimension..The only thing I didn't like was not being able to hide the dust container on the left, as I didn't want to use it and it sometimes obscures some floating pieces..There is one thing I have to agree with, sometimes you only need to be almost a whole piece away from the correct spot and it'll click into that spot.. I would not have minded if there was an option to set the 'autolock' to a much smaller range..But all in all, it's a great puzzle game, and I wasn't even annoyed by the little imp, I even missed her when I accidently turned her off with <delete> and there is no way to restore her (until the next puzzle) if you pressed it accidentally..To be honest, I bought this game in a bundle with Pixel puzzle 2: birds (which I propably won't like as much due to the images) and some other games on indiegala for only 2 euro's..

												While a lot of Puzzle games would have the common goal of putting the pieces together, if the developer started to integrate other means of effects, with a level-up or achievement system then it could be a masterpiece. This game is one of them.Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime has very unique effects and animations and a very vibrant colour scheme that I like.
